text: Number 106, Compco Corporation, Petitioner, versus Day-Brite Lighting, Incorporated.
Mr. Chief Justice and Associate Justices of this Honorable Court.

Do I understand from what you've told us so far and particularly right now, that you're whole case depends upon the fact, and it is a fact, that the respondent had a design patent which protected it for some five years in this case?
I would hate to argue the case without that.

Well, if the respondent in this case had never applied for a design patent and -- and nonetheless sued you in the District Court and let's assume, diversity jurisdiction for unfair competition and hadn't prevailed under the law of unfair competition of Illinois.
You'd have quite a different case, wouldn't you?
He'd been very hard put because there were no cases in Illinois that have anything to do with this.
Well now the respondent did prevail, of course, in his unfair competition claim in this case.
And then the court purport to be applying an Illinois law or a federal law --
So, when you say, he would've been hard put to prevail, that's contrary to what happened in this case, isn't it?

Except that the telling testimony, I don't think, could have been adduced because, without a patent, if this had been the superior product that we admit that it was, a superior just to a certain extent, not enough to enjoy the patent status, he could not have kept others out of the field.
So -- so that brings us back, I suppose, to my original question.
Suppose there had been no patent.
Let's see if I get your question, Mr. Justice Black, that --
But what I get is -- what's -- what I'm talking about is this.
That would be the law of unfair competition.
Well, unfair competition, what he was doing.
It seems to me -- it seems to me that your petition for certiorari may be stated a little better than you have.
But, in my presentation here I was relying upon the aggravated situation of the fact that the patent had been in effect.
Well, it shows -- it shows very clearly that they couldn't get a patent.
-- very clearly that they couldn't get the benefit of a monopoly through a patent.
But it doesn't show -- that doesn't -- certainly it does, does it, whether they can get a monopoly under the states?
That to me is clearly improper as far as Illinois is concerned.
Mr. Chief Justice, Honorable Associate Justices.
Mr. Chief Justice, if the Court please.
Well, was that, a copyright or design patent?
But here we're talking -- let's get back to the Coke bottle in contrast to this.
Suppose I could sell eau de cologne in -- in Coke bottles, couldn't I?
That's a difficult question to ask in view of the holding in Illinois because certain states still say that there has to be direct competition.
That -- may -- maybe yours is far enough away that we wouldn't do that.
(Inaudible) case, there was confusion, you tell me.
Because some workman decided that he should call up Day-Brite rather than Compco to come and repair these fixtures.
That evidence doesn't help you, does it?
But, on the other hand, that is the only instance of confusion.
Who was -- who was then, presumably, a sophisticated expert in his -- in this limited area?
